stem: Which finding best distinguishes anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) syndrome from carpal tunnel syndrome?

choices.B: Weakness of FPL/FDP with failed 'OK' sign but no sensory loss
choices.C: Atrophy of interossei with digit 5 numbness
choices.D: Wrist drop with dorsal hand numbness

rationale_correct: AIN is a pure motor branch of the median nerve; sensory loss is absent, and 'OK' sign weakness is characteristic.

rationale_distractors.A: Median sensory symptoms point toward CTS rather than AIN.
rationale_distractors.E: Isolated thenar atrophy without sensory symptoms is not the typical early CTS presentation.

evidence.citation: Selski D. Nerve Injuries of the Upper Limb (Slides). 2022.
